head.title: Campus Life: Swarthmore; Dropping Books, 37 Students Enter A Library Race

With midterms approaching this week, 25 male and 12 female Swarthmore College undergraduates took a break from their books last Sunday to take part in the annual McCabe Mile - an 18-lap race amid the bookshelves in the McCabe Library basement.
Running in the men's race for the third time, Paul Harrison, a senior from Stratford, Conn., majoring in economics, won for the second year in a row. His time was 5 minutes, 24.5 seconds.
A first-time entrant, Margaret Cooley, a junior from Rochester majoring in literature, won the women's race in 6 minutes, 20.2 seconds.

Carolyn Comiskey, a senior history major from Darien, Conn., and Caroline Soter, a senior majoring in sociology and anthropology from Lake Bluff, Ill., entered the race dressed as ''nerds,'' carrying backpacks, books and a calculator. They finished last in the women's race, their times being the slowest recorded in the event's 21-year history at 10 minutes, 15.2 seconds.

Instead of a starting pistol, the races began with the starter reading passages from a book - from the writings of Mao Zedong for the women, and from a book by Percy Shelley for the men - and then slamming the books shut. One runner, Kerry Ann King, a senior philosophy major from Manhattan, correctly identified the passage from the book and, as a reward, was allowed to move to the front rank of runners at the starting line.
First prizes were rolls of Scott toilet tissue in honor of Thomas McCabe, a former chairman of the Scott Paper Company for whom Swarthmore's library is named.
The races attracted almost a hundred spectators, many of whom climbed on top of shelves to get better views.

The race originated in 1969, when two students started running amid the stacks to let off nervous energy during exam week. The practice continued, with other students joining in, until the race became a tradition.
